dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Hey B, so you know Shopify, right? The e-commerce giant? Uh, been hearing some pretty rough news about them lately.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Hey B, so you know Shopify, right? The e-commerce giant? Uh, been hearing some pretty rough news about them lately.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Thanks to skyrocketing demand for its online business-building tools, the Ottawa-based e-commerce giant has brought a windfall to its public market investors. Its value peaked at $84 billion last week, briefly making it the most valuable company in Canada...

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, absolutely, A. It's, like, really taken a hit. I mean, their value just plummeted to $84 billion last week. And get this, the CEO, Tobias Lutke, his net worth has basically gone bankrupt, with like, $6 billion in debt. Wild, right?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, absolutely, A. It's, like, really taken a hit. I mean, their value just plummeted to eighty four billion dollars last week. And get this, the C E O, Tobias Lutke, his net worth has basically gone bankrupt, with like, six billion dollars in debt. Wild, right?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Its value peaked at $84 billion last week, briefly making it the most valuable company in Canada, and pushing the net worth of its 39-year-old CEO Tobias Lutke north of $6 billion.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, that's wild. It's because of, you know, falling demand for their in-person business-building tools, apparently. But here's the kicker, the article points out this *one* early investor, Bessemer Venture Partners, and their story is, um, unexpectedly positive?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, that's wild. It's because of, you know, falling demand for their in-person business-building tools, apparently. But here's the kicker, the article points out this one early investor, Bessemer Venture Partners, and their story is, um, unexpectedly positive?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In the past month, Shopifys share price has doubled after it generated $470 million in revenue in the first quarter, as demand for its online tools has skyrocketed from brick-and-mortar retailers who have been forced online by the COVID-19 pandemic.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: [interrupts] Right? It's totally counter-intuitive! So, Bessemer, they first threw in $5.5 million into Shopify's final funding round, kind of against their better judgment, the article says.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right? It's totally counter-intuitive! So, Bessemer, they first threw in five point five million dollars into Shopify's final funding round, kind of against their better judgment, the article says.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The firm first invested $5.5 million in the companys initial funding round, and after additional investments built a 26% stake worth $500 million when it went public in 2015.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Mmm, okay. And they built up this huge stake, like 26%, worth $500 million. The article mentions that if they had held onto it, until, say, today, it would be worth like $22 billion. But then it calls that a 'net loss.' I'm so confused.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Mmm, okay. And they built up this huge stake, like twenty six percent, worth five hundred million dollars. The article mentions that if they had held onto it, until, say, today, it would be worth like twenty two billion dollars. But then it calls that a net loss. I'm so confused.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: By exiting Shopify two years ago, Bessemer left at least $17 billion on the table. ... Bessemers stake in Shopify stands out as a significant missed opportunity in venture investing...

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, that's where the irony really kicks in, A. See, they *didn't* hold it. That $22 billion figure? That's what it *would* be worth *now* if they'd kept it. But what Bessemer actually did, which was super smart, was sell off their shares way back.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, that's where the irony really kicks in, A. See, they didn't hold it. That twenty two billion dollar figure? That's what it would be worth now if they'd kept it. But what Bessemer actually did, which was super smart, was sell off their shares way back.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Bessemer had redistributed all its shares back to its partners by the end of 2018, when the company was worth $15 billion.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, so they, like, got out at the right time?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, so they, like, got out at the right time?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly! They actually made, get this, 80 to 100 times their initial investment. So, that 'net loss' comment is just pure sarcasm because they *chose* not to ride it all the way down. They had, um, a crystal ball, as their partner Alex Ferrara put it.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly! They actually made, get this, eighty to one hundred times their initial investment. So, that net loss comment is just pure sarcasm because they chose not to ride it all the way down. They had, um, a crystal ball, as their partner Alex Ferrara put it.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: While Bessemers one-time stake in Shopify might prove a once-in-a-lifetime type tech position, Ferrara says the firm will gladly take its realized returns on the deal: between 80x and 100x its initial investment. Says the venture capitalist: We didnt have a crystal ball.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Wow. So while, like, Shopify's CEO and other early investors were, you know, getting pauperized, Bessemer was actually cashing in? That's some serious timing.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Wow. So while, like, Shopify's C E O and other early investors were, you know, getting pauperized, Bessemer was actually cashing in? That's some serious timing.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Some of Shopifys early investors were being minted as billionaires even before the pandemic struck, including its CEO Lutke, his father-in-law Bruce McKean, and a couple who invested $750,000 early-on, as Forbes reported in February.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Totally. And it highlights a really important thing about venture capital. You know, Professor Will Gornal from UBC said VC funds are often under pressure to post losses on investments over a shorter period, then sometimes buy shares back from their own investors.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Totally. And it highlights a really important thing about venture capital. You know, Professor Will Gornal from U B C said V C funds are often under pressure to post losses on investments over a shorter period, then sometimes buy shares back from their own investors.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Venture capital funds are typically under pressure to post returns on investments in private startups over a relatively short period of time, between five and 10 years, says Gornal. Once a company goes public, a venture firm will often sell its shares back to its own investors...

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So it's about knowing when to exit, rather than just holding forever, even if the theoretical future value looks massive.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So it's about knowing when to exit, rather than just holding forever, even if the theoretical future value looks massive.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Precisely. It's not always about the biggest *potential* number, but the realized return. And honestly, for Shopify, the pandemic actually made things worse for their in-person tools, which is kind of ironic for an e-commerce company, forcing retailers online.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Precisely. It's not always about the biggest potential number, but the realized return. And honestly, for Shopify, the pandemic actually made things worse for their in-person tools, which is kind of ironic for an e-commerce company, forcing retailers online.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Shopify is among a handful of technology companies that have surged in value as the COVID-19 pandemic has forced society to rely on online tools.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, it's a real mixed bag out there. Some tech companies, like Zoom, actually soared during the pandemic, while others, like Shopify's specific business model, really struggled.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, it's a real mixed bag out there. Some tech companies, like Zoom, actually soared during the pandemic, while others, like Shopify's specific business model, really struggled.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Shopify is among a handful of technology companies that have surged in value as the COVID-19 pandemic has forced society to rely on online tools.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: For sure. It just goes to show, um, even in a booming market, or in this case, a really tumultuous one, smart exits can make all the difference. Bessemer, they definitely nailed that.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: For sure. It just goes to show, um, even in a booming market, or in this case, a really tumultuous one, smart exits can make all the difference. Bessemer, they definitely nailed that.
